0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Atopic dermatitis: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily
  • Cerebral edema: 500 to 1500 mg/kg IV as 30% solution in D5W, D10W or invert sugar at rate not exceeding 4 mL/min; MAX 120 g/day urea
  • Congenital ichthyosis of skin: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily
  • Debridement: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily
  • Dry skin: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily
  • Eczema: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily
  • Elective termination of pregnancy: after transabdominal tap of the amniotic sac, administer 40% to 60% urea solution (in D5W), equal to the volume of amniotic fluid removed, via intra-amniotic infusion; MAX volume 200 to 250 mL (usually 80 g urea) administered slowly while observing for adverse reactions
  • Glaucoma: 500 to 1500 mg/kg IV as 30% solution in D5W, D10W or invert sugar at rate not exceeding 4 mL/min; MAX 120 g/day urea
  • Hyperkeratosis: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily
  • Psoriasis: apply topically to affected area(s) twice daily

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Cerebral edema: 500 to 1500 mg/kg IV as 30% solution in D5W, D10W or invert sugar at rate not exceeding 4 mL/min
  • Cerebral edema: (under 2 yr of age) 100 mg/kg IV as 30% solution in D5W, D10W or invert sugar at rate not exceeding 4 mL/min

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Cerebral edema
  • Congenital ichthyosis of skin
  • Debridement
  • Dry skin
  • Eczema
  • Elective termination of pregnancy
  • Glaucoma
  • Hyperkeratosis
  • Psoriasis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• severe renal impairment
  • hypersensitivity to urea or other product ingredients
  • active intracranial hemorrhage
  • dehydration
  • liver failure
  • hereditary fructose intolerance (aldolase deficiency) (invert sugar diluent)
  • ruptured membranes (aborption)
  • cervical stenois, uterine fibroids (abortion)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• liver function impairment (increased ammonia load)
  • kidney function impairment
  • diabetes, sickle cell disease (increased hemolysis/thrombosis risk)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Parenteral-Local: The mechanism by which urea causes fetal death and abortion has not been elucidated but may be related to damage of decidual cells by hypertonic urea and subsequent release of prostaglandins, which induce uterine contractions . Hypertonic urea induces fetal death .
  • Systemic: Cerebral edema-Elevates blood plasma osmolality, resulting in enhanced flow of water from tissues, including the brain and cerebrospinal fluid, into interstitial fluid and plasma. As a result, cerebral edema, elevated intracranial pressure, and cerebrospinal fluid volume and pressure may be reduced. This effect is evident early in the course of infusion as long as a gradient between plasma and intracellular urea exists. As urea diffuses into the cells and the gradient diminishes, the effect diminishes.
  • Glaucoma-Elevates blood plasma osmolality, resulting in enhanced flow of water from the eye into plasma and a consequent reduction in intraocular pressure.
  • As the concentration of urea in glomerular filtrate increases, reabsorption of a proportional amount of water is prevented, resulting in increases in rate and volume of urine flow.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Systemic: GI tract: Metabolites: ammonia and carbon dioxide

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intravenous
    • dilute to a 30% solution with D5W or D10W
    • infusion rate should not exceed 4 mL/min
    • do not administer through the same administration set with blood
    • in elderly patients, do not infuse through veins in the lower extremities
  • Topical
    • when applying to skin, rub in until completely absorbed
    • when applying to nails, let dry uncovered or apply and cover with bandage
    • avoid contact with eyes, lips or mucous membranes

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• cerebral edema: intracranial pressure
  • dermatologic conditions: symptomatic improvement
  • glaucoma: intraocular pressure
  • blood ammonia levels in patients with liver impairment

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• The intravenous form may cause syncope, nausea, vomiting, headache, disorientation, or oliguria.
  • It is important to maintain adequate hydration during intravenous therapy to prevent dehydration.
  • When applying topical preparations to nails, advise patient to let drug dry uncovered or apply and cover with bandage.
  • Patient should not apply cosmetics, or other skin products to treated skin areas when using topical preparations. Advise patient to avoid drug contact with eyes, lips, or mucous membranes.
